div1.p: Belroi Birthplace of Walter Reed, Made Public Shrine

div1.head: Newspaper clipping, [...and The Norfolk Landmark], [October 15, 1926]
div1.p:
BELROI, BIRTHPLACE
OF WALTER REED,
MADE PUBLIC SHRINE

Gloucester County Home Ded-
icated; Tribute Is Paid To
“Father of Sanitation”

Gloucester, Va., Oct. 15.--(AP)--“Bel-
roi,” birthplace of Dr. Walter Reed,
restored virtually to the condition in
which it was at the time of the boy-
hood of the great public health leader,
was dedicated today as a national
shrine before several hundred persons
who had gathered to do honor to the
“father of public health work.”

The exercises held near here were
under the auspices of the Medical So-
ciety of Virginia, and the Walter Reed
Memorial Commission through whose
instrumentality the restoration was
made. Tributes of the highest order
were paid the conqueror of yellow fever
by several spectators and many nota-
bles were among the audience. During
the ceremony planes from Langley
Field circled over the home.

Dr. Edward C. S. Taliaferro, chairman
of the commission, acted as master of
ceremonies, explaining the purpose of
the gathering was to dedicate to the
world the birthplace of that eminent
physician, Dr. Reed, who gave of his
time and energies unstintingly that
mankind might be freed forever from
the scourge of yellow fever.

Dr. Clarence Porter Jones, of New-
port News, ardent worker for the res-
toration of the small frame building in
which Dr. Reed was born, gave the
history of the Walter Reed memorial,
telling of the origin of the idea with
C. K. Weaver, of Newport News, a na-
tive of Gloucester, in 1923. He traced
the subsequent steps to the acquisition
of the property in April of this year.
Outlining the motives for the restora-
tion, Dr. Jones said they were “first
to honor a great military hero, the
first one who had achieved fame for
saving life; second, to encourage re-
search.

“There is no better way to stimulate
research than to tell the world the
story of Walter Reed. The commis-
sion is determined it shall be told in
every school and college in America. It
will kindle the young hearts with a
zeal to do something for humanity.

“It will bring forth fruit a thousand
fold.”

The speaker characterized Dr. Reed
as the first epidermologist, the greatest
benefactor to the Tidewater, the great-
est health educator that has ever
lived.

“He was an international figure,” Dr.
Jones declared in conclusion, “ranking
no less than Jennor Pasture, Lister,
McDowell, Sims and Long. His image
should be cast in gold and placed in
the public squares of every city in the
world.”

A letter was read from Mrs. Wil-
minia Fleet Taliaferro, president of the
Gloucester County Women's Club, un-
der whose direction the furnishings of
the Reed home were restored. She was
unable to be present.

Dr. J. D. Clements paid a glowing
tribute to Dr. Reed in introducing Dr.
Lawrence T. Royster, of Norfolk, who
spoke on “what Walter Reed means to
medical research.” Dr. Royster char-
acterized the Reed home as “the birth-
place of an immortal,” declaring that
“by common consent the name of Wal-
ter Reed is placed in that galaxy of
brilliant investigators: Pasture, Koch,
Lister, Jennor, Von Bochring, Morten
and Long and the brillance of that
galaxy is increased by the addition
of his name.”

During his discourse he traced the
efforts of the great physician which
culminated in the conquest of yellow
fever and paid a tribute to his devotion
in often risking his life for humanity.

Col. J. R. Kean was introduced by
Representative S. Otis Bland, of the
First district, the speaker being a man
who had been associated with Dr. Reed
in the army. He traced the early and
later life of Dr. Reed through his dis-
covery of the mosquito as a transmitter
of disease. The Rev. Dr. James C.
Reed, brother of the eminent army sur-
geon concluded the program with the
benediction.
